title: Joseph Pulitzer
summary: Joseph Pulitzer (/ˈpʊlɪtsər/ PUUL-it-sər;[2][lower-alpha 1] born József Pulitzer; Hungarian pronunciation: [ˈjoːʒɛf ˈpulit͡sɛr]; April 10, 1847 – October 29, 1911) was a Hungarian-American newspaper publisher of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and the New York World. He became a leading national figure in the Democratic Party and was elected congressman from New York. He crusaded against big business  and corruption, and helped keep the Statue of Liberty in New York.
